name: My Calendar I

similar_questions.title: Determine if Two Events Have Conflict

title: My Calendar I
content:
You are implementing a program to use as your calendar. We can add a new event if adding the event will not cause a double booking.

A double booking happens when two events have some non-empty intersection (i.e., some moment is common to both events.).

The event can be represented as a pair of integers startTime and endTime that represents a booking on the half-open interval [startTime, endTime), the range of real numbers x such that startTime <= x < endTime.

Implement the MyCalendar class:

  • MyCalendar() Initializes the calendar object.
  • boolean book(int startTime, int endTime) Returns true if the event can be added to the calendar successfully without causing a double booking. Otherwise, return false and do not add the event to the calendar.

 

Example 1:

Input
["MyCalendar", "book", "book", "book"]
[[], [10, 20], [15, 25], [20, 30]]
Output
[null, true, false, true]

Explanation
MyCalendar myCalendar = new MyCalendar();
myCalendar.book(10, 20); // return True
myCalendar.book(15, 25); // return False, It can not be booked because time 15 is already booked by another event.
myCalendar.book(20, 30); // return True, The event can be booked, as the first event takes every time less than 20, but not including 20.

 

Constraints:

  • 0 <= start < end <= 109
  • At most 1000 calls will be made to book.

discussion_posts.name: lenka91
discussion_posts.content: The BST solutions are very cool, but I wonder why to do such structure, if we can use simple array with for cycle. As several people shared for solution (Worst: T: O(n), S: O(n)). Does someone know why to do it the complex BST way?

discussion_posts.name: summerbleach
discussion_posts.content: O(n) using vector, why was i sorting the vector, it is unnecssary? just go through the vectors.\nto further make it better, we can use: BST and it will be logN. In case of a skewed bst, there is a chance of becoming O(N) however,\nso height balanced- bst, maybe????

discussion_posts.name: PuneethaPai
discussion_posts.content:
Question only says:
- In calls to MyCalendar.book(start, end), `start` and `end` are integers in the range [0, 10^9].

But never asserts that `start <= end`. Even in test case when I reverse `[start, end]` to `[end, start]` it is producing same results. 

In my opinion I expect `MyCalendar.book(start, end)` to return `False` when `end < start`, irrespective of previous calls.

![image](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/310486f0-6c3b-49f5-be31-8ed8755e2834_1623317065.4192786.png)
